member.name: T:MimeKit.Encodings.Base64Decoder
member.summary: Incrementally decodes content encoded with the base64 encoding.
member.remarks: Base64 is an encoding often used in MIME to encode binary content such as images and other types of multi-media to ensure that the data remains intact when sent via 7bit transports such as SMTP.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Encodings.QEncoder
member.summary: Incrementally encodes content using a variation of the quoted-printable encoding that is specifically meant to be used for rfc2047 encoded-word tokens.
member.remarks: The Q-Encoding is an encoding often used in MIME to encode textual content outside of the ASCII range within an rfc2047 encoded-word token in order to ensure that the text remains intact when sent via 7bit transports such as SMTP.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Encodings.UUDecoder
member.summary: Incrementally decodes content encoded with the Unix-to-Unix encoding.

remarks.para: The UUEncoding is an encoding that predates MIME and was used to encode binary content such as images and other types of multi-media to ensure that the data remained intact when sent via 7bit transports such as SMTP.
These days, the UUEncoding has largely been deprecated in favour of the base64 encoding, however, some older mail clients still use it.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Encodings.UUEncoder
member.summary: Incrementally encodes content using the Unix-to-Unix encoding.

remarks.para: The UUEncoding is an encoding that predates MIME and was used to encode binary content such as images and other types of multi-media to ensure that the data remained intact when sent via 7bit transports such as SMTP.
These days, the UUEncoding has largely been deprecated in favour of the base64 encoding, however, some older mail clients still use it.

member.name: T:MimeKit.IO.BoundStream
member.summary: A bounded stream, confined to reading and writing data to a limited subset of the overall source stream.

remarks.para: Wraps an arbitrary stream, limiting I/O operations to a subset of the source stream. If the is -1, then the end of the stream is unbound.
When a is set to parse a persistent stream, it will construct s using bounded streams instead of loading the content into memory.

member.name: T:MimeKit.IO.MemoryBlockStream
member.summary: An efficient memory stream implementation that sacrifices the ability to get access to the internal byte buffer in order to drastically improve performance.
member.remarks: Instead of resizing an internal byte array, the chains blocks of non-contiguous memory. This helps improve performance by avoiding unneeded copying of data from the old array to the newly allocated array as well as the zeroing of the newly allocated array.

member.name: M:MimeKit.IO.MemoryBlockStream.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: Creates a new with an initial memory block of 2048 bytes.

member.name: M:MimeKit.IO.MemoryBlockStream.ToArray
member.summary: Copies the memory stream into a byte array.

member.name: T:MimeKit.IO.Filters.ArmoredFromFilter
member.summary: A filter that armors lines beginning with "From " by encoding the 'F' with the Quoted-Printable encoding.

remarks.para: From-armoring is a workaround to prevent receiving clients (or servers) that uses the mbox file format for local storage from munging the line by prepending a ">", as is typical with the mbox format.
This armoring technique ensures that the receving client will still be able to verify S/MIME signatures.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.ModificationDate

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.ReadDate

member.name: P:MimeKit.ContentDisposition.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size parameter.
member.remarks: When set, the size parameter typically refers to the original size of the content on disk. This parameter is rarely used by mail clients as it serves little purpose.

member.name: T:MimeKit.ContentEncoding
member.summary: An enumeration of all supported content transfer encodings. .
member.remarks: Some older mail software is unable to properly deal with data outside of the ASCII range, so it is sometimes necessary to encode the content of MIME entities.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.Default
member.summary: The default encoding (aka no encoding at all).

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.SevenBit
member.summary: The 7bit content transfer encoding.
member.remarks: This encoding should be restricted to textual content in the US-ASCII range.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.EightBit
member.summary: The 8bit content transfer encoding.
member.remarks: This encoding should be restricted to textual content outside of the US-ASCII range but may not be supported by all transport services such as older SMTP servers that do not support the 8BITMIME extension.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.Binary
member.summary: The binary content transfer encoding.
member.remarks: This encoding is simply unencoded binary data. Typically not supported by standard message transport services such as SMTP.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.Base64
member.summary: The base64 content transfer encoding. .
member.remarks: This encoding is typically used for encoding binary data or textual content in a largely 8bit charset encoding and is supported by all message transport services.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.QuotedPrintable
member.summary: The quoted printable content transfer encoding. .
member.remarks: This encoding is used for textual content that is in a charset that has a minority of characters outside of the US-ASCII range (such as ISO-8859-1 and other single-byte charset encodings) and is supported by all message transport services.

member.name: F:MimeKit.ContentEncoding.UUEncode
member.summary: The uuencode content transfer encoding. .
member.remarks: This is an obsolete encoding meant for encoding binary data and has largely been superceeded by .

member.name: T:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint
member.summary: A content encoding constraint.
member.remarks: Not all message transports support binary or 8-bit data, so it becomes necessary to constrain the content encoding to a subset of the possible Content-Transfer-Encoding values.

member.name: F:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint.None
member.summary: There are no encoding constraints, the content may contain any byte.

member.name: F:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint.EightBit
member.summary: The content may contain bytes with the high bit set, but must not contain any zero-bytes.

member.name: F:MimeKit.EncodingConstraint.SevenBit
member.summary: The content may only contain bytes within the 7-bit ASCII range.

member.name: T:MimeKit.NewLineFormat
member.summary: A New-Line format.
member.remarks: There are two commonly used line-endings used by modern Operating Systems. Unix-based systems such as Linux and Mac OS use a single character ('\n' aka LF) to represent the end of line where-as Windows (or DOS) uses a sequence of two characters ("\r\n" aka CRLF). Most text-based network protocols such as SMTP, POP3, and IMAP use the CRLF sequence as well.

member.name: F:MimeKit.NewLineFormat.Unix
member.summary: The Unix New-Line format ("\n").

member.name: F:MimeKit.NewLineFormat.Dos
member.summary: The DOS New-Line format ("\r\n").

member.name: T:MimeKit.GroupAddress
member.summary: An address group, as specified by rfc0822.
member.remarks: Group addresses are rarely used anymore. Typically, if you see a group address, it will be of the form: "undisclosed-recipients: ;".

member.name: T:MimeKit.InternetAddress
member.summary: An internet address, as specified by rfc0822.

remarks.para: A can be any type of address defined by the original Internet Message specification.
There are effectively two (2) types of addresses: mailboxes and groups.
Mailbox addresses are what are most commonly known as email addresses and are represented by the class.

Group addresses are themselves lists of addresses and are represented by the class. While rare, it is still important to handle these types of addresses. They typically only contain mailbox addresses, but may also contain other group addresses.

The name of the mailbox or group.

member.name: T:MimeKit.InternetAddressList
member.summary: A list of email addresses.

remarks.para: An may contain any number of addresses of any type defined by the original Internet Message specification.
There are effectively two (2) types of addresses: mailboxes and groups.
Mailbox addresses are what are most commonly known as email addresses and are represented by the class.

Group addresses are themselves lists of addresses and are represented by the class. While rare, it is still important to handle these types of addresses. They typically only contain mailbox addresses, but may also contain other group addresses.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.Headers
member.summary: Gets the list of headers.
member.remarks: Represents the list of headers for a MIME part. Typically, the headers of a MIME part will be various Content-* headers such as Content-Type or Content-Disposition, but may include just about anything.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentDisposition
member.summary: Gets or sets the content disposition.
member.remarks: Represents the pre-parsed Content-Disposition header value, if present. If the Content-Disposition header is not set, then this property will be null.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentType
member.summary: Gets the type of the content.

remarks.para: The Content-Type header specifies information about the type of content contained within the MIME entity.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentBase
member.summary: Gets or sets the base content URI.

remarks.para: The Content-Base header specifies the base URI for the in cases where the is a relative URI.
The Content-Base URI must be an absolute URI.
For more information, see http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2110.txt

member.value: The base content URI or null.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the content location.

remarks.para: The Content-Location header specifies the URI for a MIME entity and can be either absolute or relative.

Setting a Content-Location URI allows other objects within the same multipart/related container to reference this part by URI. This can be useful, for example, when constructing an HTML message body that needs to reference image attachments.
For more information, see http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2110.txt

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimeEntity.ContentId
member.summary: Gets or sets the content identifier.

remarks.para: The Content-Id header is used for uniquely identifying a particular entity and uses the same syntax as the Message-Id header on MIME messages.

Setting a Content-Id allows other objects within the same multipart/related container to reference this part by its unique identifier, typically by using a "cid:" URI in an HTML-formatted message body. This can be useful, for example, when the HTML-formatted message body needs to reference image attachments.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimePart.ContentTransferEncoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the content transfer encoding.
member.remarks: The Content-Transfer-Encoding header specifies an auxiliary encoding that was applied to the content in order to allow it to pass through mail transport mechanisms (such as SMTP) which may have limitations in the byte ranges that it accepts. For example, many SMTP servers do not accept data outside of the 7-bit ASCII range and so sending binary attachments or even non-English text is not possible without applying an encoding such as base64 or quoted-printable.

member.name: P:MimeKit.MimePart.FileName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the file.

remarks.para: First checks for the "filename" parameter on the Content-Disposition header. If that does not exist, then the "name" parameter on the Content-Type header is used.
When setting the filename, both the "filename" parameter on the Content-Disposition header and the "name" parameter on the Content-Type header are set.

member.name: M:MimeKit.MessagePartial.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: Creates a new message/partial entity.
Three (3) parameters must be specified in the Content-Type header of a message/partial: id, number, and total.
The "id" parameter is a unique identifier used to match the parts together.
The "number" parameter is the sequential (1-based) index of the partial message fragment.
The "total" parameter is the total number of pieces that make up the complete message.

member.param: The id value shared among the partial message parts.
The (1-based) part number for this partial message part.
The total number of partial message parts.

member.param: The maximum size for each message body.

member.name: T:MimeKit.Multipart
member.summary: A multipart MIME entity which may contain a collection of MIME entities.

remarks.para: All multipart MIME entities will have a Content-Type with a media type of "multipart". The most common multipart MIME entity used in email is the "multipart/mixed" entity.
Four (4) initial subtypes were defined in the original MIME specifications: mixed, alternative, digest, and parallel.

The "multipart/mixed" type is a sort of general-purpose container. When used in email, the first entity is typically the "body" of the message while additional entities are most often file attachments.

Speaking of message "bodies", the "multipart/alternative" type is used to offer a list of alternative formats for the main body of the message (usually they will be "text/plain" and "text/html"). These alternatives are in order of increasing faithfulness to the original document (in other words, the last entity will be in a format that, when rendered, will most closely match what the sending client's WYSISYG editor produced).
The "multipart/digest" type will typically contain a digest of MIME messages and is most commonly used by mailing-list software.
The "multipart/parallel" type contains entities that are all meant to be shown (or heard) in parallel.

Another commonly used type is the "multipart/related" type which contains, as one might expect, inter-related MIME parts which typically reference each other via URIs based on the Content-Id and/or Content-Location headers.

member.name: P:MimeKit.ParserOptions.CharsetEncoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the charset encoding to use as a fallback for 8bit headers.
member.remarks:
and
use this charset encoding as a fallback when decoding 8bit text into unicode. The first charset encoding attempted is UTF-8, followed by this charset encoding, before finally falling back to iso-8859-1.
